messageBody:
--- Dave Astels <dave@...> wrote:
> So then, where does that format come from in the problem in hand?
> You
> must certainly have a format defined.. or how could you write either
> save or load?

What I'm saying is that your tests (like your end users) don't care
what the format is, they only care that storage and retrieval works.
If you're working with serialization, you're not really 'defining the
format' so much as using an existing framework.

Actually, that's a good point I should've caught the first time.
Java's serialization framework shouldn't be the thing under test here.
One could argue that the framework is complex enough that you might
misconfigure it, but I think that misconfiguration would be more
apparent from the save/load interaction, rather than examining the file
format.

Hmm, in this I guess I'm assuming that this thing's state is easy to
examine after deserializing. If that's not the case for some reason,
then I think you'd also want to think about why that's the case before
just going with examining serialization files.

> > Even in
> > that case, though, testing that stuff saved with saveLicense can be
> > loaded with loadLicense isn't a bad thing to do.
>
> Yes. Agreed. But try to avoid using a file to do it.

Definitely. Another poster (was it you, Dave?) suggested that String
streams are the way to go, and I agree with that. If you need to share
these things between tests, make them fixtures and share them that way.
